For those who don't know how a AmA work here's a short description of how they work on terms of what you guys get to do. (This is from my POV)

1. Sign in/up for Reddit and go to the link they will provide. I recommend signing up before the AmA goes live so you can get used to Reddits lay out. It can get a bit confusing.

2. Realize that Squad doesn't have to answer your question or even acknowledge its exsistance.

3. Think of your question before hand and have it structurally sound and to the point.

Example of something that is cool to ask and will possibly get answered. "Are Propellers or Boat Hulls ever thought of being planned?" (Just realize that such a question could be answered with. "There's a mod for that."

Examples of something not cool to ask. Anything from these lists. http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/36863-What-not-to-suggest http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/44952-Already-Suggested-List

"Hey I have this idea I was thinking of. It would be cool to see a rocket thingy that goes slowly and glows a lot and uses a special fuel but is better than the Ion and Nerva engines."

4. With the shear amount of people that will more than likely attend this AmA, Repeats of questions will be present. It is recommended to Ctrl F (AKA Find command) your question before you post it to avoid cluttering the board with the same thing.

5. Linking additional info is fine just don't expect them to read the entire article. Taking snippets out for your question and just linking the article as a source in your main post is preferred.

6. If someone that is not squad asks for clarification on what you mean. You should do so. If it is confusing to others it could be confusing to Squad. Confusing questions tend to get over looked a lot.

That's all I got. Hope Y'all enjoy the AmA!

I find AMAs far more interesting after the fact, because I don't have to worry about finding the new content in a massive reddit thread where nothing is sorted or obvious. I suggest you ask a question or two, watch only those questions, and then after they stop the AMA officially go back and read everybody else's questions. It'll keep you from participating in those questions but it saves about 99% of the frustration many (well, at least I) have with the site.
